commits.commitMessage:
LE_TRACE enclosed in do-while(0)

Encloses all multiline macro to allow calls to the macro that are unscoped

Changes to make LE_FATAL_IF, LE_FATAL, LE_ASSERT consistent with all other
macro calls such that it also ends with a semicolon (;)

Resolves: LE-14712

commits.subject: LE_TRACE enclosed in do-while(0)

commits.commitMessage:
Replace sleep() with le_thread_Sleep()

Replaced sleep() calls with a new le_thread_Sleep() function that will use
nanosleep() instead of sleep() as sleep() is implemented with the SIGALRM signal
which may introduce some bugs.

Resolves: LE-8202
Change-Id: I14a2c70097813089b82ddb09ee68e67cfada0922
commits.subject: Replace sleep() with le_thread_Sleep()

commits.commitMessage:
Introduce KConfig for Legato build configuration

The KConfig settings subsume a number of disparate settings that were
previously controlled by various environment variables and preprocessor
defines.  The legacy environment variables are still used to populate
the initial values if no configuration is present, however the KConfig
output has become the single point of truth for these values going
forward.

The default behaviour of "make" and "make <target>" is preserved.  In
addition, "make menuconfig" and "make menuconfig_<target>" can be used
to explicitly change the configuration values.

The largest changes are the addition of the new KConfig files defining
the options, and extensive modifications to the Makefiles to generate
and use the configured values.  Most of the rest of the changes are
modifying preprocessor directives and values to use the new
configuration names.

Resolves: LE-10145 LE-10147
Change-Id: Idb5aa4d4086cf005b8115a56afb0f20c4053742e
commits.subject: Introduce KConfig for Legato build configuration

commits.commitMessage:
Provide default mechanism for softdog

Instead of having a compulsory declaration for PA_WDOG_*, this
change provides a default behavior relying on the 'softdog' Linux
module.

If the PA_WDOG_DEVICE (/dev/watchdog by default) is available,
this PA won't try to load any kernel module.

Otherwise, if the kernel module to use (PA_WDOG_MODULE) is externally
defined, the PA defaults to panicking if it cannot load this module,

If the module is not externally define, it tries to load the 'softdog'
module and disable itself if the module can't be loaded.

The fact that the PA fails if the module can't be loaded or not can
be forced through the PA_WDOG_MODULE_REQUIRED option.

Resolves: LE-8684
Change-Id: I90e723e4e88f0ac60e88ca1a936c4469ab13b9d0
commits.subject: Provide default mechanism for softdog

comments.message:
Hi Enoch,

The watchdog devices on ar758x/ar759x are like these below, can we change them ?

/dev/msm_watchdog0
/dev/msm_watchdog1
/dev/msm_watchdog2
This needs to be configurable for a generic PA.  There should also be an option to not load anything, as watchdog may be built in to a custom kernel.
This should be configurable as well, although not as essential as above.

I think you can make use of string literal concatenation and just do system("/sbin/modprobe " STRINGIZE(PA_WDOG_MODULE)).  

I think I would try to make PA_WDOG_MODULE a string (i.e. something like -DPA_WDOG_MODULE=\"/dev/watchdog\"), but I'm not sure if that works with mkTools.
I think it should just #error if PA_WDOG_DEVICE is not set.  Otherwise it's just going to spam the log with "Failed to kick watchdog" as every kick with fail with EBADF.
